answers.answer: The informed consent obviously lists rare complications.  The biggest "risk" you probably have is inadequate correction.  The multifocals are usually known for giving "acceptable" acuity at most distances, but usually not awesome vision at any distance.  Most of the time you end up sacrificing a little bit of acuity at one or more distances in order to gain all of the distances w/o glasses.I don't know if you are "jumping the gun".  This is really a personal descision and a little bit of a gamble no matter what you decide to do.  If you have monofocal IOL's installed, you will almost assuredly need glasses...either reading glasses or dystance vision glasses or both.  The only way for you to stay out of glasses is with a multifocal design.

Please review all my postings going back to December of 2005 under the Cataract Archive in various categories.  Hope this will help in your decision making process.  I am thrilled with the outcome after having my new ReZooms installed.  It will take at least four months for your brain and the new ReZooms to get in sync.  The quality of vision is unmatched compared to seeing the world through cataracts.Hopefully, "eyecu" will post to give you some additional insight to considering the ReZooms.

Why the rush? From the info you supplied, you have a slow forming (sclerotic) type of cataract that may take another 6-10 yrs before you would definitely require surgery. Especially, since it is not at present interfering with your work! And during this time the entire field of multi-focal implants will have more time to mature.  I am a 67 yr. old physician who recently had a very successful Rezoom/Restor implantation and it only took 2 weeks- after my 2nd implant- until I had excellent (20/20) bilateral uncorrected vision for near, intermediate and distant. But I definitely waited to have my surgery until it was non negotiable.  It took me over 1 month to gather data in regards to which implants would work best for me- given I was determined to be spectacle free after the implants. So give it a lot more thought in the short time you have available. By the way June 1 is tomorrow & Fri is June 2!

question: I am a dentist, 45+ y/o, with type 2 diabetes, well controlled.  I have worn contact lenses for 36 years.  At my annual dilated eye exam 6 years ago, I was told I had cataracts developing.  We've followed the progress of the cataracts every year at the dilated eye exam.  My most recent exam was approximately 1 month ago and I was told a lense replacement could be done any time.  I have been noticing nighttime vision differences and during the daytime i've had trouble focusing sometimes.  The opthalmologist who examined me recently said my eyes are very healthy otherwise.  I have been getting progressively more presbyopic for a couple years but have not yet bothered to correct it.  We were waiting for the multifocal to come out to in a sense "kill 2 birds with 1 stone".  Now I'm still very functional and my dentistry has not been affected by my vision, yet.  I'm scheduled for eye surgery for the ReZoom IOL this Friday, June 1st.My question is - Am I jumping the gun on this?  I've read the informed consent on this and I've got to admit there is some pretty serious complications that can result, not the least of which is inadequate correction requiring glasses or contact lense wear anyway.  Can anyone shed some light on this and please state your credentials if you answer.
title: ReZoom IOL - is this the right time to do?
